breaking_news.title: Notepad++ update infrastructure hijacked to deliver backdoor
breaking_news.summary:
State‑sponsored attackers compromised the hosting provider that serves Notepad++ updates, redirecting traffic to malicious servers that delivered a new backdoor dubbed Chrysalis. The intrusion was an infrastructure‑level breach, not a flaw in the Notepad++ code, and it persisted for months before the update mechanism was hardened.

Millions of developers who install Notepad++ on Windows and Linux received malicious updates that could execute arbitrary code, exposing source code and credentials. The campaign has been linked to the China‑linked Lotus Blossom (also known as apt41) group, raising serious supply‑chain concerns for widely used developer tools.

breaking_news.title: CISA confirms active exploitation of VMware ESXi sandbox‑escape flaw
breaking_news.summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) verified that ransomware gangs are exploiting CVE‑2025‑22225, an arbitrary‑write vulnerability in VMware ESXi that enables a VM‑escape to the host kernel. The flaw was patched by Broadcom in March 2025, but attackers are still leveraging it to gain full control of hypervisors.

Enterprises running ESXi, including many Fortune 500 companies and cloud service providers, face ransomware encryption of virtual machines and potential data exfiltration. The rapid weaponization of this zero‑day underscores the critical risk of unpatched virtualization infrastructure.

breaking_news.title: Critical SolarWinds Web Help Desk bug exploited in the wild
breaking_news.summary:
Attackers are actively exploiting a critical remote‑code‑execution vulnerability (CVE‑2025‑40551) in SolarWinds Web Help Desk, a flaw rated 9.8 CVSS that was disclosed and patched only days earlier. Exploitation allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected servers.

U.S. federal agencies and private enterprises that rely on SolarWinds WHD have been ordered to patch immediately, as the bug can lead to full system compromise and lateral movement. The rapid emergence of an exploit for a freshly patched bug highlights the high‑risk nature of supply‑chain software used across critical infrastructure.

breaking_news.title: APT28 weaponizes new Microsoft Office zero‑day in Operation Neusploit
breaking_news.summary:
Russia‑linked APT28 (Fancy Bear) launched Operation Neusploit, exploiting the freshly disclosed Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE‑2026‑21509 in malicious RTF documents that deliver the MiniDoor and PixyNetLoader loaders. The zero‑day allows remote code execution on victim machines before the patch is applied.

The campaign targeted government agencies in Ukraine, Slovakia and Romania, compromising sensitive communications and internal networks. The swift weaponization of a newly patched Office bug demonstrates the advanced capabilities of state‑sponsored actors and the urgent need for rapid patch deployment.
affected_entities: Government agencies of Ukraine, Slovakia, Romania

breaking_news.title: React Native CLI (Metro) zero‑day exploited to deliver malware
breaking_news.summary:
Researchers observed active exploitation of CVE‑2025‑11953, a command‑injection flaw in the @react-native-community/cli Metro development server that permits unauthenticated remote code execution. Attackers have been sending crafted POST requests to compromised development environments, dropping Rust‑based malware before the vulnerability was publicly disclosed.

Companies and developers that build mobile apps with React Native are at risk of supply‑chain compromise, as malicious payloads can be injected into build pipelines and ultimately reach end‑users. The high CVSS score (9.8) and early exploitation make this a critical threat to the broader JavaScript ecosystem.

breaking_news.title: NGINX servers hijacked to redirect user traffic
breaking_news.summary:
A threat actor is compromising vulnerable NGINX web servers and reconfiguring them to redirect legitimate user traffic through attacker‑controlled backend infrastructure. The campaign leverages default credentials and misconfigurations to gain control of the web server’s proxy settings.

Given NGINX’s prevalence in web hosting, cloud services and SaaS platforms, the abuse can lead to credential theft, malware injection and service disruption for a wide range of organizations. The attack underscores the importance of hardening web server configurations and monitoring outbound traffic anomalies.

breaking_news.title: AI‑assisted breach gains AWS admin rights in under ten minutes
breaking_news.summary:
Researchers documented a cloud intrusion where an attacker used AI‑driven tooling to move from initial foothold to full administrative access in an AWS environment in less than ten minutes. The exploit chain combined exposed IAM credentials with automated privilege‑escalation scripts generated by large language models.

The incident highlights the emerging risk of AI‑augmented attacks against cloud infrastructures, threatening any enterprise that relies on AWS for critical workloads. Misconfigured IAM policies and exposed access keys can enable rapid, stealthy takeovers, prompting urgent review of cloud security hygiene.

breaking_news.title: Open VSX supply‑chain attack spreads GlassWorm via malicious extensions
breaking_news.summary:
A compromised developer account on the Open VSX Registry was used to publish malicious versions of four popular VS Code extensions that embed the GlassWorm loader. The malicious extensions were signed and distributed through the official marketplace, delivering the payload to macOS and Windows users.

Victims of the compromised extensions experience credential theft and crypto‑wallet compromise, illustrating the danger of open‑source extension ecosystems as a supply‑chain attack vector. The incident affects millions of VS Code users and raises concerns for Microsoft’s extension distribution model.
